content:
I suggest you move back to oauth. Normal password, just do not work going forward. That is a choice of Google, not the Thunderbird folk. If you have two factor authentication, you might have to disable it while you add your account, but having it working you should be able to simply change to oauth and it will step you through the process of authenticating.

Right click the folder you are having issues with (except the italic ones) and in properties make sure you are set to include the folders when getting mail.

Check in your google settings here https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0/#settings/labels that the specific labels are enabled to show in IMAP. Not all are.
creator: MattAuSupport

I ran back through the configuration, and the hints at the bottom (https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-gmail) without any change.

IMAP is enabled in my gmail by default. I disabled 2-factor on gmail.

Hope you look at this and eureka hits and you tell me which foot I should stand on :)

Cheers, --Mark

In alto a destra, qualunque sia il tipo di visualizzazione dei messaggi( classica, estesa o verticale) c'è un pulsante "opzioni di visualizzazione dei messaggi" rappresentato da tre rettangolini con a fianco un mini cursore, cliccando li bisogna selezionare "ordina per data" e poi più sotto ci sono le voci "crescente" o decrescente", queste ultime due opzioni fanno si che i più recenti siano in basso o in alto. Saluti

content:
Almost certainly Norton is the culprit, trying to intercept your secure connection to the server.

These are some generic suggestions to avoid problems with anti-virus software.

Create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile

Don't let your anti-virus software scan incoming and outgoing messages.

Don't let your anti-virus software scan attachments.

Don't let your anti-virus software intercept your secure connection to the server.

Remove any add-ons your anti-virus software may have installed in Thunderbird.

Keep it working. http://kb.mozillazine.org/Keep_it_working_-_Thunderbird

And last but not least, backup your Thunderbird profile on a regular basis. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile
creator: christ1

Second, I suggest you just reinstall thunderbird to stabilize where you are and then report issues. (Note: I do not understand the 32-bit x64 comment.)

content:
1) The ticket 150321 was allocated in an e-mail sent by Mozilla Support <product-help@firefox.com> who I suppose posted my problem here. 2) The description of my operating system as "32-bit Operating System, x64-based processor" came from Control Panel - System. I use a AMD FX-6300 six core processor which could operate a 64 bit operating system, but I installed Windows 10 32-bit in order to support some legacy software and hardware. Thunderbird used to operate satisfactorily until recently. In addition to the blank drop-down menus, I am also plagued by "You haven't set up a chat account" with its inoperative buttons.

I have an old laptop with Thunderbird 6 installed which I may have to resort to. I re-installed Thunderbird 115 yet again, but this gave only partial short-lived relief. Thunderbird is quite slow to load alongside these present troubles.
creator: ksw40

content: Is there legacy software that Thunderbird is interacting with? I mention that, since that is why you are using the 32-bit version. I also suggest checking what software might be interfering with Thunderbird; often, that is caused by well-meaning antivirus products. What you're experiencing doesn't fit in normal problem areas, and that is why I'm thinking something else is happening here, since you state that Thunderbird works, and then it doesn't.
creator: davidsk

content: I suggest doing a backup first of the profile. If using Windows, that would be at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird (not generally needed, but I like being safe.) Now download and install thunderbird. It will overlay any remaining remnants. I have no idea what may have deleted the prior version, possibly an antivirus program?

content:
If you have the correct settings and the antivirus is just the built-in Windows Security, there are a couple of steps that might help:

First, uncheck 'Place a copy in' in Account Settings, Copies & Folders, as Hotmail/outlook.com accounts automatically copy sent messages to Sent, and second, remove all entries for the account from Saved Passwords in Settings, restart TB, enter the account password in the OAuth window to allow access. A single oauth:// entry will be stored in Saved Passwords for incoming and outgoing (as long as cookies are accepted in TB Settings).
creator: sfhowes
